addressleaf.section:
The copie of my l
re
to my L. T
re
r 25 Sep
t
.

page.lettertext:
fol.29r
May it please yo
r
good L. It is nowe ten dayes
and more,
at
e Deputies of
e
States
which were
sent to take advise of
Co. Maurice
and
e
Councel,
returned to
e
Hage.
And sins I have
observed,
at both they and
e rest have bin
dyvers tymes together, to consult upon
e maters
in so muche as I supposed,
at either they
before this, would have sent for me unto
their College, or deputed some to tell me, to
what effect they had resolved. But being
secretly informed that they had varied in
opinions, and surceased for
e tyme to
deliberat upon it, I requested to have au-
dience in their publicke meeting, where I
put them in remembrance of all
e course
of my proceeding in this negotiation: howe
long it had bin, sins
e mater was proposed:
howe many l
res
her
Hig
es
had written unto
them: and howe great occasions were presen-
ted, that she might worthelie disdaine this
long delaieng of their aunswear: w
t
suche
other allegations, as fitted that argument.
Wherto their speeches returned were so vehement,
and earnest, and full of solemne protestations,
as I can not calle to minde,
at I have heard
them at any tyme doe the lyke heeretofore.
For of all
e troublesome accidents,
at hapned
among them, sins
e union of their
Provinces,
they affirmed very constantly,
at there had not
and at any tyme either busied them longer,
or grieved them more, or caried so muche
danger, if it were not well conducted, as this
proposal of her Ma
tie
. For w
ch
they urged me
exceedingly, to move her Hig
es
to consider
the composition of their gouvernment, the
humor of
e people, and the state of their
fol.29v
affaires, w
ch
in a cause of this nature, would by
no meanes admitte a speedier dispatche. They
had sent, they sayed, of purpose, to
e Councel
of Estate, to require their advise upon her Ma
ties
demaunde: w
ch
had already bin reported by
their Deputies unto them, but it prooved so de-
fective, as they were ayded nothing by yt: for
w
ch
they had resolved, to send their l
res
out
of hand, to request their presence at
e Hage,
so that they hoped very shortly, to come in con-
ference teogether, and then to growe to some con-
clusions w
ch
was
e effect of all their answear:
though I did my best endevo
r
, to drawe them
by persuasion, to some present resolution.
For my privat opinion of the sequele of this
mater, it is no other in no respect, then I have
formerly declared, by my l
res
to yo
r
L. Heere is
nothing to be heard, but complaints of all handes
that I may say in this mater, as I could never
yet in any that touched her Ma
tie
, That of all
at heeretofore I have founde in this Contrey
well affected unto her, I doe not knowe so much
as one,
at will affourd the least aide, or any
token of allowance, or favor in this mater.
The enemies Campe and ours are still together
as they were, but
at 20 troupes of ours are
going for
Picardy,
to witte 10 of this Contrey,
under Mons
r
de Nassau, and
e regim
t
of
Scottes, w
ch
are lykewise 20 Companies, under
Coronel Murrey
. And yet we thincke
at Co.
Maurice is somew
at
stronger then
M ondragon,
who hath sent away no part of his forces to de
Fuentes, nor doth not intend by Co
m
on conje-
cture, unles
e Kinge come
e stronger. Of
de
Fuentes
proceedinges, I thincke yo
r
L. intelligence
is surer then ours, and sooner brought unto yow.
fol.30r
Heere is very litle hope
at
e
Kinge
will be able
to rescue the place, aswell in regard of his want
of men and meanes, and for
e slacknesse of his
coming. And
e Enemie, we say, is already in
e rampartes, using all expedition, both by
batterie, and by mining, to frustrat his
arrival.
And so I take &c.
